If you're looking for split screen its a good choice but don't expect a huge difference from the original Gears of War - at the end of the day it's a standard remaster which means you get some bonus content and improved graphics. If you have the PC version there's no reason to play this one except split screen.  Not a system seller but its a decent game until we can enjoy Fallout 4 this fall I suppose!
Amazing game.
great product

product_title: PlayStation Vita TV Value Pack (VTE-1000AA01) (Japan Imported)
review_headline: Review of Japanese region Vita TV micro-console, Final Fantasy Heavensward variant version
review_body:
Bought the Japanese region Vita TV with the Final Fantasy Heavensward logo embellished on the top -- looks quite cool (compared to the plain-vanilla released Japanese region Vita TV micro-console bundled set currently being sold here on Amazon.com). Upon getting it, saw that it has firmware 3.10 on it and it said that a firmware update was needed. Proceeded with the firmare update and selected that English to be displayed on the main menu. Checking out the Japanese PSN store, there are numerous Japanese region Vita, PS1 game titles and PSP titles that are downloadable but the movies and anime DL selection are a bit sorely lacking (there is a more robust selection of movies to d/l on the USA region PSN site indeed). Does have an internal 1GB of memory for Vita games, Vita game demos, Vita game updates & FMV clips d/l'ed off the JPN region PSN site (but that isn't user accessible once you insert a Vita memory card). The use of an optional 64GB sized Vita memory card works like a charm on the Vita TV micro-console (it'll say that 60GB are available for use once properly formatted upon inserting it for the first time). However, if you insert a Vita memory card associated with a USA region PS Vita user account, it'll say that the content isn't compatible for use with the Vita TV console and if you wish to use it, delete the content so that it may be reformatted to be used properly.

What's cool is that if you have a Japanese PS3 user account set up on your PS3 gaming console, any of the Vita game demos, Vita game FMV clips & Japanese region PSP game demos that you've previously downloaded off of the Japanese PSN site and saved to the PS3's HDD, they can be transferred to the Vita TV micro-console's internal 1GB memory or saved to an inserted Vita memory card via USB 2.0 link cable setup -- how cool is that?

Of course, considering that this particular Vita TV micro-console is just the system itself, a supplied AC adapter, and included HDMI cable -- noDual Shock 3 controller is supplied whatsoever and one will have to sourced to be utilized when powered on.

Makes an ideal companion piece to your existing Japanese region Vita gaming handheld.

review_body: Got it on time. No problem with the case or anything.

XCom is one of the most underrated games in PS3. It did great on computer gaming but did awful in consoles salleswise. Here you get not only that premium strategy game but also Borderlands an Bioshock. Great great games in themselves. Max value for your purchase.

Very convenient, feels good in the hand. But ITS FUNCTIONALITY SUCKS! You literally have to be within 6 feet of the Xbox and be pointing it directly at it. Microsoft missed the mark with this one. It's much easier to use Xbox smart glass on your phone. :(

review_headline: It has interesting noises incorporated with the songs and I just love Disgaea what more can I say
review_body: I have yet to actually play the game but listening to the Disgaea D2 soundtrack seems to calm me down and the second disc brings nostalgia from the first game. It has interesting noises incorporated with the songs and I just love Disgaea what more can I say. I can't wait to see the female version of Laharl when I play the game.

I was having too much fun with Nintendo’s new ip when it first came out to write any review! So decided to write one now after trying all of the game’s features. Didn’t have any issues with online multiplayer. Octo valley is fun. Love the colors! Vibrant. Gameplay is fun. It’s actually is enjoyable to play. I prefer using wiimote controls to play this game.

Transform into a squid when needed. Blast others with ink. Neat idea! Only thing I wish it had more options for single player. I like the notion of identifying with animals in a game which is pretty neat. Nintendo tends to do that with many of it’s games (Zelda, Marios, Donkey Kong, Deep Ocean to name a few). I can play Splatoon with others than me without having to worry about an over saturated amount of violence. I also now have a better appreciation for squids. review_headline: No Performance Issues, Cord Needs to be Longer
review_body: The product performs just fine.  We purchased this solely for our younger daughters to use with their Just Dance games.  Camera picks their movements up just fine.  Is it exact...no, but being that they no longer have to hold a controller when dancing, makes this not such a big deal.  Our major complaint with this camera in general, is the cord that you have to connect into the Playstation  is super short.  When my husband went to Best Buy to purchase another identical one to make it longer, they told him only the manufacturer makes it and it would need to be ordered through them, online.  When we received the additional cord, it didn't fit into the original cord to extend it.  Come to find out, others have had the same issue and have posted on forums online that there is no way to extend the length of the cord at this time.  Major bummer if you're Playstation is hooked up on the other side of the room, such as if you have a media room for this kind of hobby.  We ended up having to move the entire Playstation closer to our screen, which then meant we needed to make other cords not related to this camera, longer.  More extensions needed.  Kind of a pain if you only plan on using this for Just Dance games.

product_title: BitFenix BFA-ACL-12BK6-RP 12cm 6 LEDs Alchemy LED Connect Lit, Blue - PC Mac Linux
review_headline: Nice for Computer Case Illumination especially for Windowed Cases.
review_body: These LED strip lights are a great way to highlight a Computer case. You can purchase longer strips, or connect two or more of these smaller strips together with supplied connectors. The lighting is quite bright. I have one set that is now about 4 years old, and they have not dimmed out, at least not from my own perspective, and that is with high hour usage. The strips have an adhesive backing on them. Once in a while, you might get an "old" set, that was in storage awhile, as the adhesive backing comes off of the strip. On an occasion or two, I have had to supply my own industrial double backed tape to mount these. The connectors are of decent quality, with plenty of wire to reach around your case with. I have also installed these around the I/O ports on the back of the computer, to give illumination for when you are plugging or unplugging components into the computer so you do not need a flashlight. Make sure you protect the wires from any sharp edges inside the computer case. Now go have fun!

This version of Sony's PlayStation 3 console is compact, sleek, and even stylish. As a casual gamer, this game system is satisfactory, such that it's 500 GB hard drive is more than enough to store my game data, videos, and music. It's super slim design makes for easy placement anywhere in my home where there's a TV. Plus, it is said to use less energy than it's preceding version, the PS3 slim version usually holding an average 250 GB. It shows, as older models tend to fire off like a heating system or an air conditioner after moderate to heavy use. There are no signs of the console burning out, even after several hours of gameplay. (Note: extend the longevity of your game system by not using it so often, you all know the drill.) I keep some space open around my console so it doesn't overheat. The price of the console when I bought it reflected well for my budget too, as I saw it as less than a dollar for every gigabyte storage in the console's hard drive. All in all, if you want the ultimate gaming experience without paying an arm and a leg for the newer PS4, buy this PS3. Even with changes in its design -- there is a hatch covering any inserted game disc that can be opened by pressing the eject button adjacent to the power button on the front -- the console functions in the same capacity as its older models. Some may see this as a downgrade from what is featured with the older models, but it's really of no consequence to me. It enhances that DVD/Blu-Ray kind of feel for me when inserting discs into the the console. Good price for a good device, and well worth the investment… if it doesn't burn out and experience that yellow light of death often seen with the "fat" models.

review_headline: Horror Fans rejoice...this is a must play!
review_body:
This will be a quick, non-technical review. First off, I rented this from Redbox. It took me roughly 7 and a half hours on my first run, mainly because I was looking for every clue and totem in the game. Since the game is essentially like a playable movie, I would say even if you "speed ran" the game it would still take you 4-5 hours because you cannot skip scenes. This game is awesome! If you are a fan of horror movies, this is definitely a homage to them. The overall graphics, score and atmosphere is excellent. The characters are great cliche's of their horror movie counterparts and at first I was wanting pretty much all of them to die, but as the game developed I began routing for most of them.The plot is broken into a prologue, 10 story chapters and an epilogue. The plot itself is fairly predictable, but does have a few effective twists in the last quarter of the game.

Pros:
-Horror/Slasher genre is on point!
-Visually this game is stunning, especially the lighting effects.
-Hayden Panettiere, Peter Stomare, Rami Malek and Brett Dalton are superb. The rest of the cast is great, but not standouts.
-The story was very unique (surprisingly) and had unforeseen twists.
-A LOT to discover everywhere you go
-Characters (other than Emily, Matt & Jessica) have growth over the entire story arc
-The game truly has multiple endings
-You can determine who from the group lives and dies by your actions
-Controls are simplistic and work well with the game-type
-Cinematography is eerily effective
-Ability to revisit chapters to complete collection of clues & totems

Cons:
-Cannot skip cut scenes (mainly for re-playing chapters for trophy hunting)
-Takes a few hours for the story to "take off."

review_headline: Decent End To WCW's Video Game History
review_body: WCW Backstage Assault is a mixed bag as many people since its November 2000 release have given mixed (mainly bad) reviews on the game that is Backstage Assault. I recently bought this game for a relatively cheap price to see how the game was for myself so here it is. For starters I want to say that when you play this for the first time, it's ridiculously difficult to even try and set up a match. Finally once you've managed to get past the annoying superstar selection screen, you get to choose from 7 different areas to fight your opponent in that include a truck arena, the locker rooms, the loading bay, bathrooms, the block, the parking garage, and the media center. The only available area upon first playing the game is the truck arena. All other areas must be unlocked, but I'll get to that in a moment.  Backstage Assault has a fairly large roster containing most--if not all of the WCW superstars that were on TV in 1999 and 2000. It was also the first game to feature WCW women as default characters on the roster, making it one of the largest rosters in WCW's gaming history. Among the stars and women in this game include Goldberg, Sting, Hulk Hogan, Jeff Jarrett, Major Gunns, Sid Vicious, Mona, Booker T, DDP, Kimberly, Rey Mysterio, Torrie Wilson, Scott Steiner, Miss Hancock, Vince Russo, Bret Hart, and many more. Of course with men and women on the roster, that also meant you could do several intergender matches. Want Goldberg to lay a beatdown on Major Gunns? You can make it happen. Want Torrie Wilson to beat Scott Steiner into submission? Go for it!  There are only 3 different matches to play. You can choose between regular, First Blood, or Human Torch. Regular and First Blood are pretty self-explanatory, while the Torch Match involves you having to set your opponent on fire to win the match.  There are 2 different features to play in this game that include Hardcore Challenge Mode and Hardcore Gauntlet. Hardcore Challenge Mode was pretty much similar to Mayhem's Quest For The Best Mode, only you were fighting backstage. The premise of Hardcore Challenge Mode involves you choosing a WCW superstar and playing as them through a series of backstage matches as you vie for the Hardcore, US, and World Titles. Along the way, with each match you win, you'll unlock new fighting areas, new weapons, and new women and superstars to play as.  Hardcore Gauntlet sees your superstar fight 7 other opponents in back to back matches with no time to rest or recover. If you lose a match, you can't replay it and will have to start all over again. And when the smoke clears, if you've managed to overcome and prevail in both the Hardcore Gauntlet and Hardcore Challenge Mode, then you just may find yourself among the top 10 in the Hall of Champions.  Now for the final part; gameplay. Gameplay pace moves at a similar, decent pace as it did in Mayhem. The only problem with the game is how unbelievably difficult it becomes to keep your opponent down for a 3 count. Seriously, I played a match with Goldberg against Jeff Jarrett and after nearly 5 minutes of constantly driving Jarrett into the concrete and beating him senseless with nearly every weapon in sight, he still continued to kick out every time I pinned him, time and time again. Now I'm all for a challenge, but having your opponent no-sell your attacks isn't a challenge, it's just annoying. The thing that really turns me away from the gameplay is the cheesy effects added to it. If you ever low blown an opponent, you'll be met with a cheesy boink sound effect or whistle sound effect. Like why? Just why? And of course, to call the action for WCW's last video game is Tony Schiavone and Bobby Heenan.   Overall: For WCW's final video game, this wasn't all it could've been. Somewhere, some genius back in 2000 thought it'd be a great idea to completely toss out the wrestling ring and have nothing but backstage fighting. While on paper it may have sounded like a good idea, actually going through with it wasa mistake as fighting backstage in every match gets old really quick. Kind of like most things on WCW television during the time this game came out, Backstage Assault took something cool and ran it into the ground until the point it was no longer something interesting or fun. Had they kept the in-ring aspect in this game and worked on adding other features, then this could've been a really great game. Something not many know is that a follow up to Backstage Assault was being planned but it would be called Mayhem 2. So it was ultimately a sequel to Mayhem but had the same concept as Backstage Assault. Set for a Playstation 2 release in October 2001, it looked to be the greatest WCW game never made. Mayhem 2 would still take place backstage, but with a Def Jam like theme with bigger and larger areas to fight in and even a story mode with branching stories. Unfortunately because WCW went out of business in March 2001, the game never made it past its early developing stage. Instead, we're left with this average, somewhat forgettable game that is Backstage Assault to put the exclamation point on WCW's video games. Overall, Backstage Assault is a decent game. It's fun to finally get to play as the women of WCW as well as play as a lot of the popular stars that were in WCW during that time, but after 7 or 8 matches, the game loses its flavor and becomes bland and lackadaisical. If you're a big fan of WCW and/or its video games, then give this a try; otherwise, just settle for Smackdown 2 Know Your Role--which outshone this game when it came out just weeks after Backstage Assault

Let me first say that after having played madden 15 which was a very discouraging undertaking on many levels, I cancelled my pre-order for 16!
However, wanting to play football, I said to myself, well let's see what happens with 16!.
For some reason, it seems sacrilegious for EA sports to give us the consumers who purchase its sports games a blessing without adding a curse!
Don't get me wrong, I like what they have done to Madden 16! I just don't like the way they did it.
The running game is an impossibility with the exception of a few plays that actually work because within the new animations, the offense moves at an almost snails pace in play action which allows the defense to pounce before the quarterback can hand the ball off. In addition, the defense on running plays lives in the backfield because the block is very stagnant and doesn't resemble they way the pros run block from an offensive line point of view. With regards to passing, it's actually fun, however, if the receiver doesn't catch the ball after you have gone for the aggressive catch, there will be most like an interception. If you somehow overthrow a wide open target, there will be most likely an interception. When I play games against the computer as I have been lately using the Seahawks against the Chargers on All Madden Level I have been getting beat almost everytime because the offensive line blocking doesn't hold up. My QB has gotten sacked consecutively so fast at the snap of the ball that it happens within the blink of an eye and leaves me asking what just happened! Rarely does this happen in professional football in this manner!
One other thing that I wish EA would change. Football is a natural game played in natural way. This game is not fully natural the way shooting games are. I don't like the fact that the QB is sacked when a defender is with 5-7 yards. The QB, it seems cannot complete the natural throwing motion which you and I would be able to do in similar situations! The QB has to have a throwing radius of 180 degrees. EA falls short in this aspect because it allows the position of the defenders to dictate the accuracy of the throw!

Lastly, there are three things to look forward to in this addition of Madden;

1.Exhilarating long distance catches...the QB can actually throw the ball above defenders...(hope they never stop this feature)
2. More interceptions because of the new wr/db interactions
3. More sacks because the O-line blocking should have been better!

Finally!, there is still room for improvement and it looks like EA is on the right track with this addition of Madden.
The question is, how long will it be before we get a simulated football game that can do everything?

product_title: PS2 USB Energy Metal Arcade 3 in 1 Dance Pad with Handle Bars
review_body: Don't waste your money on this thing.  I bought one hoping to get back into my DDR prime days and this thing is nothing but disappointment.  I ordered the first one, and it shipped just fine, however after plugging it in and playing I realized that the left arrow did not function.  Not just it missed from time to time.  It did not function AT ALL!  I contacted the seller and shipped it back for a exchange.  After getting the exchange I plugged that one in and it played just fine,  FOR ONE DANG PLAY SESSION!  It then promptly did the exact same thing and the top arrow and left arrow did not function at all. It has to be either cheap wiring or cheap sodding of the sensor bars.  But either way, it is supremely frustrating as a old time DDR player that cannot make their own metal pad to play at home.  Find better pad (which is unlikely)  or find ways of making one yourself and save yourself the pain and hundreds of dollars that I've just gone through.

review_headline: Try these things if you run into an Error!
review_body:
I wanted to get this game for my daughters as I know I enjoyed playing it as a kid. It worked without issue on one of our laptops and on another we kept running into an error. It is not the discs fault or the software... this is an old game and is not compatible with certain windows versions and settings.

All you have to do is right click on the icon for the game, go to properties, go to compatibility, and select "run this program in compatibility mode FOR" and select one of these: WINDOWS 98/ME/2000/XP. This will help it run.

Now If you run into a graphics issue where the cats look like a bunch of triangles or similar you need to change the resolution of your screen to one it is compatible with which a safe bet is 640 x 480. In the same place as you change your compatibility you can change it to run in that resolution, HOWEVER, this sometimes doesn't work and you have to manually change your resolution to that size.

Make sure you apply the changes and close the Properties window.

Good luck!

With Rock Band 4 destined to be released in a couple months, I figured that I may as well give my thoughts on Rock Band 3.......for the Nintendo DS! So not only do we have a Rock Band game on the PSP and a conversion of Lego Rock Band for the DS, but we also get a version of the numbered sequel on the go! While certain home-to-small-screen transitions of video games have been handled as half-hearted cash grabs, others give the handhelds a complementary experience, and that's exactly what Rock Band 3 provides.

If you've played the other portable Rock Bands before, you'll know what to expect from this one. If not, don't worry; I got ya covered. Unlike the Guitar Hero games on DS, you don't need a peripheral to play this game, so not only is it less expensive to boot, but it can even be played on a Nintendo DSi or 3DS. Instead, you play using the DS's own buttons. The A, B, Y, and X buttons are all for hitting the notes (they are assigned to the specific colors of course). The unique difference (between consoles and DS anyway) is that you gain control of all four instruments, each with their own layouts of notes, and you must hop around to use them via the L and R buttons. To do well at earning stars on your performance, you must react quickly when one instrument's note layouts ends and another starts up next to you and keep hitting the notes without missing one for note streaks. And of course, the mic can be used to double your scores temporarily (a la Guitar Hero's Star Power)

All things considered, the resulting rhythm gameplay is neat and addicting. Playing songs, especially on difficulties like Hard mode, make the game fast-paced and the combo-triggering can make for a good motivation to try and keep at it. The music selection amounts to a healthy 25 songs, and most of them are goodies I'd be happy to jam to. I actually like this game more than I do Lego Rock Band, because not only are the graphics much more interesting to look at, but what I wasn't so fond of in Lego was that you were able to stick with one instrument during gameplay, and if you do that, you'd just experience repetitive rows of notes throughout the song. Here, Rock Band 3 requires that you keep going and help the entire band stay on their feet, especially considering not taking part in the other note tracks would mean the other instruments may end up in desperate need to survive with the whole band. It keeps gameplay NOT repetitive by making use of all four note tracks instead of making that an option. And as far as I can tell, the campaign isn't rehashing songs as much as Lego Rock Band's.

It's Rock Band on the DS made more fun than before, and for that I wholeheartedly recommend this game to rhythm game fans, and for those interested in playing a Rock Band game, but don't feel like going through the tedium and spending of buying each peripheral. It's inexpensive, portable, and a great play. Now if only there was a 3DS version of Rock Band 4.wasn't so fond of in Lego was that you were able to stick with one instrument during gameplay, and if you do that, you'd just experience repetitive rows of notes throughout the song. Here, Rock Band 3 requires that you keep going and help the entire band stay on their feet, especially considering not taking part in the other note tracks would mean the other instruments may end up in desperate need to survive with the whole band. It keeps gameplay NOT repetitive by making use of all four note tracks instead of making that an option. And as far as I can tell, the campaign isn't rehashing songs as much as Lego Rock Band's.

It's Rock Band on the DS made more fun than before, and for that I wholeheartedly recommend this game to rhythm game fans, and for those interested in playing a Rock Band game, but don't feel like going through the tedium and spending of buying each peripheral. It's inexpensive, portable, and a great play. Now if only there was a 3DS version of Rock Band 4.

product_title: TNTi™ T-1200 Controller Core - Xbox One Rechargeable Battery with Play and Charge Power Cable
review_body:
So most of you who have some game console know that you always need a extra battery pack of some sort to keep you able to play your games for all day. I'm sure many of you use lots of batteries if you have kids who play the game all day. But now you might have a solution to this issue of yours and you won't have any MISSING batteries.

When I tried this charger out the remote control was completely dead. I placed the battery into the controller and let me tell that it has a lot of power because it has been two days and the controller is still rolling. I usually go through packs of batteries in a week which costed me money I don't have to be wasting. We go through so many batteries because we play like almost day since it's summer and there's not much to do. The kids also cause me a high light bill too. I like that when the battery dies you could use the USB wire cable as a a wired controller too. Since the wire reaches 9 feet long this is awesome too because you sit from the tv and still play. You can also use the charger while it's charging but I don't do that because I don't want to mess up the charger. When I went to charge it the charging only took a little over 2 hours to fully charge. I would definitely recommend this charger because it works great with the Xbox one control and it's worth the price.

*I received this product in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. All words are my own.

product_title: MOGA Mobile Gaming System for Android 2.3+
review_body:
Works great on 3rd party programs that support it. Syncs fast via bluetooth. Very responsive. Moga Pivot App is required but is free and very non-intrusive. Having your phone in the little cradle thing is optional but not required.
However there are 2 things about it that I don't like.

1: It takes 2 triple A batteries (not included). However they seem to last quite a while.
2: There is no D pad. For games that need just a D pad or both D pad and analog stick this can be an issue. You can map the other analog stick to be a D pad but it doesn't feel right, especially on retro titles.

Those 2 issues are small for the price of this controller. It's really nice.

BOTTOM LINE: (2015) Beautiful ships, nice cities, good music here and there. Tech issues, credit-grubbing, mediocre. Three and a half stars.  Set-up: SWTOR takes a very long time to download. The SWTOR website identifies your computer every time you login. I assume they do that to annoy people into buying their security keys not just to be creepy.  Subscription: The Old Republic (SWTOR) is free to a certain level now. I actually became a subscriber anyway (about $15 a month) to have the full experience. Your rewards for being a subscriber are: much faster experience gains, in-game dlc gifts that are teased months before you get anything to keep you hooked, and just enough Cartel* coins each month to make you realize how expensive the stuff in the cartel is.  Tech: I played SWTOR for about a month then the game wouldn’t load anymore. There were smaller problems before that, connection loss etc. I don’t know if my internet provider throttled the game to death (as it does every website and video) or it was a SWTOR thing but I was already kind of bored with the game.  Game: The combat is ok. You and your companions share up to 3 abilities. Beyond that you can’t really customize your character's abilities except by buying stuff with credits. The graphics are fine (the ships are particularly impressive). The game just isn't that engaging and it’s too focused on credits.  A short list of what you have to pay to do in SWTOR: Increase the size of your inventory. Go to another planet. Get to a new location on the planet.  Upgrade your gear. Upgrade your companion’s skill to maximum. Use Legacy “rewards.” To access each part of a new stronghold. You even pay to sell things to other players on the Galaxy Trade Network.  Multiplayer: Flashpoints allow you to join a group of players to go kill a bunch of people. Sometimes players fall out but group combat was fairly smooth. Its run, fight, thanks for the fight and everybody goes their separate ways. I understand. They’re busy. Credits don’t make themselves.  I was on a PVE story-server, as opposed to an RP-PVP server. Mass PVP didn’t appeal to me. In between typical social media “discussions,” players occasionally yell about their guilds. I accepted a personal invite. No one in the guild ever chatted. I assume we were all invited at random and were focused on our own goals. An MMO might be good if you already know people you are going to play with. Otherwise you use (and are used by) strangers like companions in a video game anyway.  It was never not-interesting being in the Star Wars universe but the wonder wore off surprisingly quickly. You are surrounded by the environment but not immersed in it. Kind of like a theme park. There was an Old Republic video game that’s supposed to be good. I'll probably try that. Maybe it will run.  *The cartel is a catalog you access when you are logged in but it is not part of the game.

review_headline: Fun, but with a sprinkling of bugs
review_body:
I am a fan of open world games, but missed playing this one on the PS3. I decided to try the PS4 version and while I found it enjoyable, it's not among my favorite open world games. I found the learning curve in the beginning to be a little steep. I never could quite get down the mechanics of fighting. Sometimes Wei would just stand there as I was hitting the buttons to get him to move. I'm not sure if it was because I was mashing the buttons too hard or if it was a glitch. Luckily, you can buy upgraded outfits that come with weapons. The game became much easier once I had a sword and a gun. Still, there were little bugs where my gun would randomly disappear or Wei wouldn't pick up a knife that was dropped by another enemy.

I was able to overlook the glitches because this game is fun overall. I loved driving around the open world of Hong Kong. It was fun to play a game that wasn't set in the U.S. The game features lots of side missions that I enjoyed playing. My favorite side mission was the drug bust one where you have to hack a camera and then catch a criminal remotely. The characters in this game slowly grew on me. At first, I found them all rather irritating, but Wei and his best friend grew on me to the point where I cared what happened to them.

Overall, this game is worth playing if you're a fan of open world games. It's a great value and it comes with all of the DLC. I enjoyed playing it while waiting for the blockbuster games to come out this year.

Nowhere in the description says that you need to be connected online to play this game.  Keep this in mind if you plan to buy.  Waste of money, thanks Bungie for saving me 20$ that i can spend in a better game.

review_headline: If you want a poorly manufactured, shoddy console, look no further
review_body: I think this might be one of the most poorly made products I have ever purchased in my life.  I love the concept of this console and was very excited to receive it and try it out.  At first, it worked perfectly.  Within less than a week of its arrival, the jack for the AC adaptor plug had somehow loosened to the point that the power plug no longer stays plugged in.  The slightest touch will dislodge the power cord, and there goes your game!  If that wasn't bad enough, the included controllers do not work on SNES games, at least not on my console.  Even SNES controllers which work perfectly on a SNES do not work when plugged into the SNES ports.  I did not drop or otherwise abuse the console.  I am truly amazed at how fragile and poorly built this thing is.

okay. Straight to the point:
Not everyone is going to like this game.
I however, have put 1250 hours into this game, it is so addicting. The reward system is set up to give you completely random rewards and for most content you aren't guaranteed anything. If you get this you will be hunting down a particular weapon for hundreds of hours. If you don't like the sound of that, it's not for you.
As of right now the story is completely absent from destiny. This may change with the new expansion: The Taken King. It looks promising and if you're just getting destiny it is a great deal. The original game plus 2 dlc's ($20 a piece) plus the Taken King expansion for $60.
Despite its current lack of story, the competitive multiplayer is amazing. In no other first person shooter do you get the visual feedback on your screen like in destiny. It shows how much health an opponent has left and is all around great fun. Weapon balancing is an issue right now for the competitive multiplayer, as only a few top tier "exotic" weapons rule this game mode. However they are releasing a patch soon to rebalance the weapons (something they do every few months) and I hope it'll bring other weapons up to par.
All in all, I have loved every second of this game. I don't know how long I will play it, but I'm not stopping anytime soon.

product_title: Atelier Shallie: Alchemists of the Dusk Sea - PlayStation 3
review_body:
If you ever thought that working in a Chinese factory was a fun way to pass your time, this game will make you very happy. If you're looking for a deep story, good mechanics and a well-crafted game world, you need to move along to another game.

I could never get into the Atelier series. They seemed custom crafted to appeal to gamers who love chirpy, super cute graphics. Atelier Shallie promised to be the best of the series so I checked it out and was very disappointed.

Graphics:
The graphics are pretty good. The environments can be a little sparse but the character design is bright and colorful with quite a lot of details. You can tell that Gust was working on attracting the neckbearded anime nerds and female Goth/Loli lovers with the designs. The menus are bright and the color palette seems to strike the right blend of gloom (the world maps) and cute (the menu screens).

Sound:
The music is bland and entirely forgettable. The character voices are stereotypically Japanese (if you play with Japanese dialogue turned on). Girls' voices are at the upper end of dog hearing and the guys are about 1 notch below. Enemies don't make much noise, at all.

Gameplay:
The main thrust of the game is doing missions and synthesizing items with alchemy. This is about 80% of the game and if you are into this kind of thing then you will love this game. The areas (just one or two screens each) can be selected and you can run through them and battle enemies and harvest items. The items and monsters respawn each time you go through. The big problem is that battles are either really easy or impossible. You'll blow through normal enemies and then you'll meet a HUGE monster that you cannot even dent. Death means nothing and you just go back to the World Map. The battle mechanics are OK and you can keep a reserve member to help defend or attack. The problem is that the battle animations are rough: enemies fade away, attack animations are choppy and the battles seem like just a waste of time. You get seemingly arbitrary amounts of experience points and there's no real way to judge if a battle will be easy other than to just try and see if you can win.

Plot:
Milquetoast Shallie or Incompetent Shallie has to do a bunch of quests because blahblahblahblah. The plot is almost nonexistent and creates no urgency or wonder or anything but "now do this quest and then after that do this one." It's like running down a checklist. None of the characters have anything but basic, stereotypical personalities.

This game has potential but falls short on an enjoyable experience. It's almost as if a design team said "what if we stopped taking time to write a plot and just made the sidequests into the main quests?"

review_headline: Best open world game I've played in a long time
review_body:
This game, omg this game! I'd been wanting this game for a long time now, but wanted to wait till I got the PS4 so I'd have more games on it.(Since I already has so many on PS3). I had gotten it since I was going to be going out of town to my Aunt's house, who doesn't have great internet(or really any at all).

My mom said I could take it with me since we'd be there for a long time. I never ONCE turned on the PS3 or used any other games what so ever. I love this game so much, it's one of the best open world games I've played in a long time. At one point I was just like to hell with the story! My mom, dad, aunt, just everyone in my family that was there started playing. We just had a ton of fun driving around, since none of use were any good at it. The story is okay, could had been better. But it's a ton of fun I honestly which some of the Assassin's Creed games were like this.
I hope Ubisoft makes another Watch Dogs, just even for the fact I can just drive around blowing stuff up.

While playing this game, it was the most I'd seen my dad laugh in along time.

All in all, great game, good game play, rather easy controls.

product_title: Endless Ocean: Blue World - Nintendo Wii
review_headline: Good Example of a Video Game as a Teaching Tool.
review_body:
I use this game as a reference guide to identify various forms of life in our oceans with adolescents and younger adults who have not had the opportunity to explore the oceans themselves. Of course, one video game is not a substitute for the real thing such as going out an exploring the world underwater. But it does become an added teaching tool in the study of marine life using visualization, imagery, and hand eye coordination. Another game to enjoy that does not glorify murder and mayhem which has become so common in video games today. One of the reasons I like Nintendo games like Deep Ocean. Hoping to see Deep Blue Ocean and similar games continue on the Wiiu and Nx.

“The best video game is the one that teaches.”
Zahor Bano Begum 1985

review_headline: Great experience from start to finish!
review_body:
Great game overall. Visuals are nicely done. Voice acting is perfect. Working through the puzzles and clues is very fun. Across 6 different cases, you get to experiment with different mechanics, each case lasting roughly 3 to 5 hours depending on how thorough you are; that's a total of 18 to 30 hours of gameplay which is very good value.

The only minor issue I had with this game is that for each case, there are several possible conclusions depending on how you choose to assemble the clues. As others have said, this means every conclusion is usually based on circumstantial evidence, meaning there is not "right" or "wrong". This may or may not be a big deal to you, and it was just a minor thing for me, but you will not have the satisfaction of solving each mystery "correctly".

Overall, this game is highly entertaining and I truly enjoyed it, and recommend it for the thinking gamer.

product_title: Pikachu Yellow - Nintendo DS Lite Complete Full Housing Shell Case Cover Replacement Kit w/ Free Tools [repair] [nintendo DS lite]
review_headline: the form of the parts are not exactly like Nintendo parts and so it can be difficult to ...
review_body: I bought this from ValueDeluxe. It took about three weeks to get here and tracking wasn't available. As for the product... it's not the highest quality (but what do you expect for 10 bucks?). The plastic is cheapish and the only "glossy" part is the top cover. The rest of the body is dry and lifeless. Also, the form of the parts are not exactly like Nintendo parts and so it can be difficult to install. I had to melt a bit here and there so that things would fit but it is not noticeable. As for installation, if you have no experience doing anything like this, don't. Sure, it's possible you could succeed, but why risk breaking a perfectly functional DS lite just to put a cheap plastic body on it? Anywho, I'm giving this two stars because 1. Proportions are all wrong and my DS didn't close properly. 2. My DS looks cheap now instead of the expected awesome. 3. Installation instructions were incomplete (no instructions on how to change the screen frames to yellow).

product_title: Command and Conquer The Ultimate Collection
review_body:
The people who have problems with this games are people that don't do their research or even look at the description. First you must meet the required specs of each game. Then as the descriptions says it is a digital download from EA. You do get a physical copy of the soundtrack and a special edition photo that comes within the case along with your digital download code. Have all that and are ok with a digital download then you'll be fine. If you are looking for a physical copy of the game then you have to buy the games by themselves or for a console.

Exp:All games play excellent on my PC. newer games lag on my laptop as it doesn't meet the video specs required of the game.
OS for both Laptop and PC: Windows 10

Note: At the moment there is no online play as the servers aren't up and will not be up for some time as EA is working on it.So you'll either have to make a Lan connection or set up your own private server.

product_title: Super Smash Bros. Edition GameCube Controller
review_body: If you play your all of your GameCube games with the thumbstick, please ignore this review. I play all of my GameCube games on the Wii and needed to replace my old controller. I heard positive reviews about the Smash Bros. GameCube Controller and since it was compatible with GameCube games, I purchased one. I tested the controller on all of my games and the controls were very responsive. The thumbstick, buttons, and C-stick were working perfectly, but I quickly discovered something alarming. The D-pad seems to be extremely sensitive to ALL of my GameCube games. When I press up, down, left, or right, it thinks I'm pressing a diagonal input. I play half my GameCube games with the D-pad and I find it frustrating that the controls aren't functioning properly. I know this controller was exclusive to Smash Bros. but it was advertised to be compatible with GameCube games. The D-pad being overly sensitive might be a flaw to these new controllers, so purchase at your own risk.

review_headline: tl;dr - Solid game but wait for a sale because $60 is a lot for a base game
review_body:
I waited to get the Sims 4 until about a week ago, as I wait for every Sims upgrade, and really any game upgrade the I know will come with expansions, etc. Why? Because when you buy a new version of a game that you have every expansion and mod known to man for and then have to revert back to playing just a base game without even bug fixes, it's always going to suck. Always. So, I've waited til there was a sale (because no Sims base game is worth $60) and picked up the basic version. Since I waited, many of the issues (no pools, no dishwashers, etc) were fixed with game patches. This is the case with pretty much every game anymore, so be aware that many "huge" or "unfixable" issues people were freaking out about have already been fixed.

First, yes, it definitely is different than the Sims 3. In a lot of ways, this is great. I don't mind a 5 second load screen between locations when it means I don't have a 5 minute load time initially. The Sims 3 took forever to get up and running, and that always annoyed me. Also, the world is what I'd call "semi-open". There are little neighborhoods that the Sims seem to be able to pop around in without a load screen, and when your Sim is out of their home lot, you still have partial control over the sim at home (you can make them "take care of self" "build skill..." and other general activities). Relationships also take A LOT longer. My first household was two Sims living together, and they aren't in love after like a day. It does seem a big more organic and not like it takes TOO long based on the Sim's lifespan. However, if you want to have a Don Juan/Juanita type Sim, it'll definitely be harder.

One of the things I do miss, kind of, from the Sims 3 is Create-a-Style. I thought I'd miss it way more than I do, though. For sure, I miss being able to make custom hair colors and modify make up colors. Even with mods, not all the mods have the exact same color of hair and soyou kind of end up stuck using one creator's hair styles. Generally, it's not a problem if you want to use someone like Skysims or Nightcrawler because they already have lots of styles out, but if it's a newer mod creator it can be annoying since they don't have like 100 hairstyles I can choose from. I also miss being able to change the bed linen colors, and the walls. However, there are a lot of built in options so generally, I was able to find something I liked fine in the base game as far as furnishings. Of course, we'll get more and better furnishings each time we pony up for an expansion pack, or if you go and look at thesimsresource.com or modthesims.com. MOST experienced Sim players already mod their games to hell and back, so I think losing Create-a-Style hasn't been as bad as it could be, but I do wish it was available for the less tech savvy among us who can only download and install custom content, as opposed to creating it (If you aren't downloading custom content from the above sites, I encourage you to start. They have content for ALL Sims games and instructions on how to add it to your game. It's very easy and really fun!).

A handful of items are "unlockable" by achieving certain things (like reaching the top of a career or something). Since I mod my games into oblivion, the idea of unlocking an item is kind of a fun side-quest type thing, as opposed to super annoying given the small amount of items overall.

Build mode is different, but I think it's MUCH better. First, there are premade rooms, which is a nice shortcut when building. Second, roofs are far more complex now. There's no auto-roof, but it's not as difficult to make cool looking roofs anymore, either. It's hard to explain how build mode is different, exactly, but it seemed easier to use. Buy mode has to be accessed through build mode, and has the same options of searching by room or by item type. Buy mode confused me for a second but I don't mind it now.

You also only get three traits per sim! That part is kind of dumb. Maybe an university pack will allow a fourth, or something, but it still seemed kind of light on the personality and I wish I could have added two more traits. :( Additionally, I think some of the skills are less intuitive. For example, you have to find an actual fishing spot to fish, as opposed to just clicking on the water or looking for a school of fish. I had to ask Google for help on that one. lol But there are more skills, so there's that.

As far as similarities, in the base game, you control your Sim at work the same way, with a handful of options. You can text

One of the new additions I didn't think I'd care about but kind of like now is the emotions. It's more complex than "Sim has to pee" "Sim is hungry" or what have you. The emotions stack, and modify each other, and while they sometimes relate to the needs (such as being uncomfortable or bored), other times they're outside the needs or sparked from other activities. Sims in certain moods can do extra things, not just with other Sims but with the world around them. This includes special paintings (there are WAY more options for painting now, in general), and getting embarrassed from sucking at playing an instrument (as well as making other sims "tense" because they suck). It helps make up for the lack of traits (still mad about that though, I'll be honest) and I think it could be fun as you get further on.

Overall, I think Sims 4 is a solid game. I haven't been tempted to go back to Sims 3, which I kept installed just in case, and I don't find myself fast-forwarding through everything or cheating to keep my Sims from freaking out and having low needs. I only have the base game at the moment, but I've probably added 100 items via mods. The expansions are cheaper this time around, it seems, but I'm entertained enough to wait. I know a lot of people are pissed about Sims 4, but Istill think it's worth playing and trying. A lot of people were pissed about Sims 3 as well. People just hate change, especially gamers. That being said, I think I would still encourage you to wait for a price drop or an Origin sale, since it's a lot less frustrating to buy a $35 game and think, this is okay but I wish it had more, and paying $60-70 for a game and thinking the same thing.

review_headline: A great charger and night light
review_body:
I've had this charger for over a year with two remotes. It works great. Just stick the remote in and it charges as expected. There are no cables or issues guiding in so it will sit just right. I thought the plastic may be too light duty, but so far OK. It has some spring/give to it. The controller stack, so shelf space real estate needed is kept limited which is nice.

The only negative thing I can possibly say about it after a year is that the LED charge lights may be too bright for some places. I'm not sure I would want it in my bedroom, or right next to my TV as it could be distracting. Take this into consideration before you get/use it. They make a nice night light in my living room, so I actually find the LED's to be a benefit.

The only improvement I can think of would be a 'gas gauge' on how far along the charge is, 25%, 50%, etc.
Brand new, good condition, on time. Thanks :)

product_title: Gears of War: Ultimate Edition - Xbox One
review_body:
I am actually a pretty hardcore Gears of War fan. I have them all. At first I was not sure I was going to get this, since I have already played the game on Xbox 360 in 2007. If you are wondering if enough is different to justify the purchase, well yes there is. The game still has that gritty dark look that so many people liked about the series. I know a lot of the early videos made the game look a lot brighter than the original. This actually is not how GOW Ultimate is. I repeat it is very dark and gritty.

One thing I do not like is the computer intelligence of your comrades is just as stupid if not more stupid then the original game. You basically just play the game by yourself. The computer controlled partners will run right out and get shot and are useless. Also I really would have liked if they would have thrown in a version of Horde in the game. I know Horde did not debut until the second game, but it has a huge following. I cannot wait until GOW 4.

review_headline: Hope Shinji Mikami gets another installment
review_body:
After all the bad reviews I took a chance and finally bought the game for $19.99 and I love it! The only bad thing about it is 50% black bars on the top and bottom but after 30 minutes and I have a 55” TV it didn’t really bother me at all just turned the lights off in the dark and good to go!. The loading time takes 36 seconds a pop after getting killed so it wasn’t that bad most other games take longer

I love to be sneaky by killing the zombies and disarm the bombs but I’m a little slow 70% got it 30% dead.. Now my god Chapter 10 that 6 legged creature is super hard (angry mode) like a snake with a rat = fast death over 100+ times I don't ever want to fight that b*tch again!, If you have problems go to this video guide http://www.gosunoob.com/evil-within/complete-chapter-walkthrough/ NOTE: don’t waste your bullets on Ruvik just run no way to kill him

The control is pretty smooth just like RE4, 5 but have big problems on the shortcut weapon inventory I keep popping the wrong button so many times and screws me up, the graphic’s are nice but not the best some parts are like a classic movie type and some screen tearing from time to time but its not that bad some reviewers just get annoyed for little things

UPDATE: I Changed the control setting to C that was a lot better !!
UPDATE: Upgrade the Harpoon Bolt to 5 that will get FIRE! better to kill her (chapter 10)
UPDATE: Chapter 15 Complete - Casual - Total Time: 35:32:06 Total Number of Death: 197 (Chapter 10, 15)

NOW the good news!! Just got the leak on Amazon France, The Evil Within the GOTY edition coming this September include the DLC The Assignment, The Consequence, The Executioner Bethesda hasn’t confirmed an actual release date for North America yet , but keep an eye out for it. Also heard that they will get an option for full screen and letterbox I will definitely buy it again !! http://community.us.playstation.com/t5/PlayStation-General/The-Evil-Within-Game-of-the-Year-Edition-on-the-way/td-p/45274387

This is a GREAT game its like Resident Evil 4, Silent Hill Downpour, The Last of us all in one and it is very fun game to play and so glad I bought it, but u might as well rent it first coz chapter 10 is very hard from the boss fight… I really hope Shinji Mikami gets another installment [The Evil Within 2] soon!!

review_headline: An amazing and surprising horror game.
review_body: Probably the most fun I've had in a "David Cage" like game (e.g., Indigo Prophecy, Beyond Two Souls and Heavy Rain) and it wasn't even made by David Cage.  A very cool game where choices do matter.  Game elements, dialog, even character deaths can change by a simple choice or the finding of a clue.  There are jump scares aplenty, however, the real horror comes from a general sense of dread and anxiety that makes you on edge the entire time you're playing.  While I did rent it from Gamefly, I do recommend purchasing it (which I will).  Sony and game developers need to know video game enthusiasts want quality games like Until Dawn.  Play it.  You'll thank me!

review_headline: Better than most make it out to be.
review_body: I really enjoyed Arkham Origins. Before purchasing it, I was a bit hesitant because of the lukewarm reviews. However, I bit the bullet, and have had no regrets. The game mechanics are very similar to Arkham City, with some minor gadget variations. Overall, the game plays great, though it does have some minor hiccups, such as a slight pause during the cutscenes, or small glitches involving the hostiles when you interrogate them. If you are on the fence about purchasing this, I would recommend you do. As of right now, I feel it has the best boss battles among the 4 Arkham games, in addition to the best story line.

product_title: Razer Sabertooth Elite Gaming Controller for Xbox 360
review_body: So first impressions, guess I will start there. You open the box and inside is a very nice controller case. Open that and you have a controller slot with some nice foam to keep your controller safe on the lid portion are two mesh pockets with a Velcro portion to keep everything tidy very nice case. The braided cable is of good length, and plugs in nice and easy. The controller is plug and play into pc which is what I am using it for. So first issue the backlit button are cheap crap. The buttons don't cover the whole slot so the light just shines straight out. Yes, it has a function to turn them off, but in messing with this option I came across problem 2. Access option to turn backlight off then go turn off rumble since I don't like rumble pressing the button to switch turns the backlight back on. So after messing around with it a bit, gave up on having both backlight and rumble turned off. Moved on trying to play the game I wanted it for Tera. This is a game I play with a controller that has to compete with people who use keyboards and mouse. So I was trying to keep playing with a controller, so for instance if I have block mapped to right mouse button and click the character will block as fast as I can click. The problem with controller is that they have that depress time was hoping this razer wouldn't. It has less depress than my xbox one controller, but the button are not very quick to respond so despite spamming B to block I block once every 2 seconds. This Is not very conducive at all considering especially in PvP I have to unblock rotate my character and re-block to block an attack coming from a different direction rapidly. So that's pretty much a right off for me but I'll continue. The thumb-sticks are very slow as well I play with max sensitivity on this game and it felt like I had cut my sensitivity in half. So again in PvP well changing camera angles and character direction needs to be rapid, I don't need a controller that lets people run circles around me faster than I can turn. Now for this "ergonomic" design the part of the controller on the outside part of the bumpers pushes outward physically making it harder to push the bumpers. I normally can use the bumper and trigger with just one finger on xbox one/360 and PS4 controller but this one was making me fight it to do that do to its bad design, also made that extra set of bumper they put into the controller very difficult to get at. This controller feels cheap overall like some knockoff. So poor buttons, bad programming  in the panel, terrible thumb-sticks and horribly ergonomic design controller, that came in a very nice case with a nice cable. I will stick with my xbox one controller.

product_title: Aweek® Plug In Cooling Fan Cooler Fan with 4 Ports USB Hub For Xbox One Xboxone Console, Black
review_body:
When I was sent this product for an honest review I didn't feel the product was necessary since the Xbox One has a large cooling fan. I was wrong, I have seen a huge improvement to my Xbox One and its performance. Not only does this product turn 2 USB ports into 4 it helps keep the Xbox One cool for extended gaming and helps prevent things like frame drop and other negative effects of overheating. It has a small noise to it but if you play with the volume at a decent number or you play with a headset it will not effect your gaming experience. Overall I believe this is a great product and I would say this item should be on the radar for any serious or casual gamer.

Again, I was provided this product in an exchange for an honest review. This did not impact my review in any way.

This isn't really a review, but mostly what I like about this game in my opinion.

Although shorter than the Xbox 360/PS3 version, Sonic Generations for the 3DS is still a fun game...BUT I wish there were more levels. They didn't even include a stage from Sonic Heroes, though I suppose the Special Stages and stage select soundtrack make up for it...I guess. One thing both versions of the game did do right however was using Chemical Plant Zone and Casino Night Zone from Sonic 2 as in my opinion those were the best, memorable stages of that game. The rival battles here were meh...not really special to me and the Time Eater boss I have to admit was less frustrating than the 360 version.

The stages are lush and beautiful especially Casino Night, Tropical Resort and Emerald Coast. A nice memory of my Sonic Adventure DX days making me wish that they ported Sonic Adventure to the GBA or DS. 2D stages of that game would've been interesting.

If Sega decides to do another Generations game during Sonics 25th or 30th anniversary I'd want a full 3D version of the original classic Sonic the Hedgehog.

Like most reviews here the game can be beaten in a few hours but Mission mode will surely keep players coming back. I've finished all missions and got S rankings in every stage so there's not much else for me to do then to improve my profile card. Pick this game up if you're a Sonic fan and want to relive those days of the Genesis and Dreamcast/Gamecube. Or else watch the playthrough videos on youtube to see how the game plays.

With regular batteries I can get maybe a week or so of really solid playing (more than 6 hours a day), but with these charge packs you are looking at about 6-8 hours total before they need to be recharged.  Not a huge issue if you have a second controller to switch to or you aren't a diehard, marathon gamer, but something to be wary of all the same.

product_title: SteelSeries Siberia X800 Wireless Gaming Headset with Dolby 7.1 Surround Sound for Xbox One, Xbox 360
review_body:
How ironic is it that my boyfriend was looking at head sets for me when I stumbled on this one?! The StealSeries Siberia P100 packs a lot of punch for something as lightweight as this!

I'm not 100% sure what my boyfriend has but it's the one in white with the ring that changes colors and the volume and such are adjustable by turning the middle part of the ear section.

Pros ---- The headphones itself (as in the fluffy part that goes on your ears) is incredibly lightweight and comfortable. I normally hate big clunky things like these (which is why I was always like nahhh when it came to buying so Beats by Dre) but these don't make me annoyed or make me feel like it's suffocating me with its size at all. I can almost barely tell it's there. The cushion on the top of the band rests nicely on top of your head giving you even more room to breathe and adjusts perfectly so that the headset stays in place. Because you know, like I know, that sometimes when games get really intense you do a lot of laughing or head movement as you're yelling at the screen. Yeah, with this, it's not going anywhere so no more of that "crap! I just dropped my headset hold on. HEY WAIT UP!" moments. I know you know what I'm talking about!

The sound quality is awesome but I still would prefer the surround sound effect that my boyfriend's white ones give out. Headphones. With surround sound. It's about as mind blowing as it sounds guys. Forreal! I do however like the sound quality that comes with these when it comes to simple MMORPG gaming. I've always played my games on mute (I'm one of those people) so to actually HEAR what's behind you? It's crazy for me. Now I see why people use headsets to play COD!

I like the options this product gives you. There are a few simple clicks of the middle button to control you music as far as back, pause and forward. No need to grab your phone to switch the song, it's awesome. Now if only they included voice command, could you imagine?! Talk about #lazygamer right?!

Cons --- It doesn't flash crazy colors like I thought it would. But that's okay, it would probably distract me. Also the microphone is a mini mic so it's tucked behind the fluff of the headphone which is fine cause you know it's there but it's not like all in your face. But I'm just one of those people who like to SEE where my mic is just so I don't feel like I'm talking to myself lol. But if you're one of those people who like that you can't see the mic, then great! Regardless of your preference, the mic is of great quality as well. I'm pretty impressed.

Now if you'll excuse me... I have a Chocobo to rent and a town to head to!nd, could you imagine?! Talk about #lazygamer right?!

product_title: HORI Battle Pad Turbo for Wii U (Luigi Version) - Nintendo Wii U
review_headline: Great fight pad and great for VC games
review_body:
This is a Wii Classic Controller made to look like a GameCube controller. It plugs into a Wii Remote and can be used with both the Wii and Wii U on the menu and in games (assuming the game in question is compatible). Naturally, the designs are designed around Smash Bros. characters, and this controller definitely feels right in that game, as it has since Melee.

The build quality is top-notch, but if you've ever bought a HORI controller, that's kind of old news to you. The plastic on the controller is matte finished, rather than the glossy finish of real GameCube controllers. It makes the controller feel slightly different than a real GC controller, but it still feels great. The ZL and ZR buttons are actual buttons, not triggers like the L and R buttons were on the GameCube, which could be a bit of a downer for some. That said, an L button was added to even out the controller.

The controller has a turbo function, but I've never really gotten into using turbo for games. The sticks are tight and pleasant to use, with little resistance. They, as with the plastic on the controller, are a different material, but still feel good. The buttons go down easily and seem to use a mechanism identical to the old GC pads - so it's not likely to stick. Finally, the D-pad blows the real GameCube's D-pad out of the water. It's much larger than a GameCube D-pad and feels an awful lot like the D-pad you can find on the Wii U GamePad, but smoother. Since the GamePad has one of my favorite D-pads, this is a very good thing.

It is more versatile than the Wii U Pro Controller at half the price - as a Classic Controller, not only can it be used with compatible Wii U games, it can also play games through the Wii Menu and can be used with actual original Wii hardware without extra setup - I've used this controller for playing Super Smash Bros. Brawl and it feels just as great as it does in Super Smash Bros. for Wii U.

Overall, there's nothing negative I can say about this controller. It exceeds expectations, it feels great, and it brings a familiar controller layout to a new generation of games.

product_title: Ratchet and Clank Future: Tools of Destruction - Playstation 3
review_body:
Ratchet & Clank Future: Tools of Destruction. (known as Ratchet & Clank: Tools of Destruction in Europe and Australia and Ratchet & Clank Future in Japan) was developed by Insomniac Games, and was released on October 23, 2007 for the PlayStation 3. This was the first Ratchet and Clank game for the PlayStation 3, and the first in the Future trilogy. In this installment, the self-proclaimed crown prince of the Cragmites known as Emperor Tachyon is after Ratchet, claiming that he is the last Lombax in the universe. He and Clank escape to the Polaris Galaxy, befriending the Markazian Talwyn Apogee and two old war bots named Cronk and Zephyr, who help the two uncover the Lombax secret, Tachyon's ultimate goal. Throughout the game, Clank encounters a mysterious race called the Zoni, who assist him at various points in the game, only to abduct him during the ending cut scene.

Tools of Destruction's weapon upgrade system introduces the need for Raritanium, an aptly-named rare resource mentioned in previous games, in exchange for certain upgrades, as well as continuous use of said weapons to upgrade them automatically.

product_title: Anker 8200 DPI High Precision Programmable Laser Gaming Mouse for PC, 9 Programmable Buttons, Weight Tuning Cartridges, Omron Micro
review_headline: Good while it lasted, but don't expect it to last very long.
review_body:
**Just a heads up for FPS guys - you can set the side mouse button to a Key, say C for crouch, which is nice. However, the side buttons merely toggle the key, even when held in. So if your play style is to crouch by holding C, you're going to crouch and come back up immediately, even if you're holding in the side button.

I purchased this mouse exactly 1 year and 11 months ago today. Within the first 3 weeks I had an issue with the laser not tracking correctly. The mouse would move in unintended directions on the screen. I wrote the company and they replaced the mouse with a new one.

Since then, it's done the job. Granted, I was trying to save a buck at the time, so I settled for this guy. It feels like a mid-grade mouse. However, within the past few weeks, I've noticed that my right mouse button does not register as well as it used to. Now I'm an avid FPS gamer, I probably play 3-5 hours per week, and occasionally I'll play an MMORPG.

The Right mouse button failures are most noticeable when sniping, the failure has robbed me of numerous kills and has even caused me to die several times.

Also, the scroll wheel seems to cry or squeal every time I use it now.

Basically, this mouse was good while it lasted, but don't expect it to last too long. Spend the extra $20 and get something that will survive the FPS abuses. I just ordered the Logitech G502 Proteus Core, I'm going to have to learn a whole new mouse :(

This game is OKAY. The multiplayer works pretty well most of the time. I really only have two gripes, and I'm sure if you play this game then you will agree with me.

1. Menu for multiplayer - This game has a multiplayer menu that jumbles everything together. I was hoping that you could go to a separate matchmaking lobby for each game - go to a lobby and pick Halo 2 snipers or rumble pit playlist. This is not the case. There is one lobby and the gametypes you can pick are must much more limited - you can pick slayer and that includes Halo 2 and Halo 3 maps. I would have really liked if there would have been a main menu that allowed to select Halo, Halo 2, Halo 3 or Halo 4 and from there went to the same menu you could expect from each respective game. This leads to...

2. Controls! - I never thought about it, but the controls changed from Halo 2 to Halo 3 and even to Halo 4. You can't just use the legacy controls for each game. They created a new "Universal" default that just doesn't quite provide the one size fits all that they intended it for. Sure, there are several variations but none of them work well with all of the games (grenade switching..deploying items). I can't believe they don't just let you customize the controls for exactly how you want them. It's not a big deal, just a little annoying.

All in all, these aren't two huge issues that should prevent you from getting the game. They, unfortunately, along with the initial poor matchmaking experience, are two common sense things, that prevent this collection from being as great as it should be.

review_headline: An adventure game way ahead of its time!
review_body:
This game is totally comparable to The Legend of Zelda in its constant action and nonlinear progression. I would consider it even better in a couple of ways; for example, you can equip multiple different weapons/armor/shields/spells and rotate them out at will depending on the situation. You have to figure out which combo to use for different opponents. It also has a leveling system, an EXCELLENT save system (you can save/load anywhere on the map except for certain hostile zones). The combat system is also a precursor to The Secret of Mana and I would even say Secret of Mana ripped this off a bit.

The music is irresistible after a few listens, the controls are snappy, and the graphics are colorful. I am really surprised this isn't more famous. CHECK IT OUT!

review_headline: Fun, Demanding and Satisfying. Great music too.
review_body:
- Introduction -

IA/VT Colorful is a recently released Japanese music game for PS Vita. It probably won't ever be released in the West, according to producer Kenichiro Takaki, so if you want to play it, import it. The menus use lots of English and there is no story to follow, so knowledge of Japanese is not necessary at all. The game is massive, featuring 60 full-length songs, all sung by a vocaloid named IA (pronounced "eee-yah").

- My Background -

I am coming to this game much more as a general music game fan than as a Vocaloid music fan. I am a big fan of music games, my favorites being DDR (back in the PS1 era) and Elite Beat Agents (NDS). I've also played a decent amount of Guitar Hero, Rock Band, DJ MAX and Bit.Trip Runner2. But I've only played a short demo of Hatsune Miku Project Diva f and I don't know much about Vocaloids. (Although this game is slowly changing that!)

- Gameplay -

The gameplay is easy to understand and fun. There are 8 different face button notes and special "colorful notes" which are triggered by any button and boost the score multiplier. I really like that there are no touch controls at all, which I have always found kind of gimmicky in music games. The goal is to try to max your combo and get as many "Cool" note scores as possible, and it's quite a rush to finally succeed and get the ultimate SSS and Perfect Combo rankings on a song.

On a technical level, the game is really solid. The note scoring system (Cool/Nice/Safe/Miss for each note) is tight and balanced. And thanks to the great visual and sound design, you get really great feedback on your timing, if you are early, late or missed it. In comparison, it seems like a lot of music games don't give good feedback on your timing. These games are either frustrating to play or unsatisfying because they introduce sloppier scoring systems to compensate. So I am really impressed that IA/VT pairs a demanding scoring system with such great feedback. This makes improving your skill easier and more satisfying than many other music games.

I started playing on Normal in "Free Play" mode. It seemed a little too easy at first, but the challenge ramped up really nicely as I unlocked songs, with lots of fun tricks and fast notes to keep me on my toes. It was a nice touch that the last unlocked songs on Normal difficulty have about the same challenge as the first songs on Hard difficulty. The challenge keeps progressing up to the final songs on Hard, which are all rated 9/10 or 10/10 for challenge.

There is also "Step Up Play" mode, which is essentially a campaign mode where each level gives you a specific song (or 2 or 3 songs in a row), applies a modifier (like random or hidden notes) and you are challenged to get at least S ranking, or a certain number of "Cool" notes. This was pretty fun and gets quite tricky too!

- Graphics -

Overall this game looks absolutely stellar. It's hard to even think of a single ugly thing in it. The UI is incredibly polished and even the default note skins look fantastic. I'm not even sure that Persona 5, when it comes out, will have better looking UI than this game.

Regarding the songs themselves, most have video animations or slideshows going on in the background, ranging from meh to awesome. Some songs you can play with costumes and 3D animations, which are cool but mainly just show IA staring out into space while walking or standing and not lip-syncing to the song. From what I've seen, Project Diva f has way higher quality song animations, but this was never really a selling point of the game for me and I think it is perfectly fine the way it is.

- Music -

I think this music is pretty cool on the whole. I've played every song at least 2 or 3 times now and most of them keep growing on me. I really like indie-rock and post-rock kind of stuffand a lot of these songs felt inspired by this kind of music. Lots of wacky, interesting rhythms. Lots of pop, electronic and metal elements. The Vocaloid singing is obviously all digital, but many of the backing guitars and drums sound like they were performed live by skilled musicians. This isn't the kind of stuff I ever imagined being in a music game, but I think it all works really well.

Still, I'm left wondering who are the people who are making these songs? I looked into one song I liked called Migawari Kibonnu. Between Youtube and Nicovideo, the song's PV has gotten around 35,000 views total over two years. This seems like an absurdly small number of views for something cool enough to be put into a video game. The song's creator was Manabe Shuichi, a mysterious person who plays bass in the band Soutaisei Riron (literally "Theory of Relativity"), produces for a young female singer named Hanae, and plays in the self-described "brutal orchestra" music collective Vampillia. I still don't even know what he looks like, but these other projects seem just as interesting and unusual as this one song that he contributed to IA Project. I suspect the backstories for the other 59 songs in this video game are probably pretty similar to this as well, which I think is pretty cool. The subculture of Japanese music represented by this game seems to be both incredibly rich and very mysterious at the same time.

- Replayability -

Like most music games, there's tons of replayability here. Each song is about 5 mins long on average, so with 60 songs included, there's around 5 hours of music to play in this game. That's a lot! With three difficulty levels, as well as a separate campaign mode, it takes around 20 hours to do everything in the game once. Replaying and mastering songs you like is of course fun too. The Platinum trophy seems like a pretty reachable goal, although maybe a little grindier than just playing the game for fun.I'm currently working on this myself. Getting the Platinum will probably take the average player around 25-30 hours and involves playing each song in the game several times, as well as playing through extra songs for each of the 59 unlockable costumes.

- Final Thoughts -

+ Really satisfying to play thanks to the tight scoring system and great timing feedback.
+ Impressive visual presentation.
+ Interesting and slightly unusual music for a rhythm game.

- Much smaller budget than Project Diva games.
- Some songs (not many) are boring or just not very fun.
- Not enough higher difficulty songs.

Overall, I think this is a really fantastic music game. It does a lot of things right, such that I feel like all of my complaints are pretty minor. I really can't put my PS Vita down, which is just like when I was playing P4G all over again. If you just like all kinds of music games, this one is definitely worth your time. More so than your Rock Bands and Guitar Heros if you have the slightest leaning towards Japanese music. If you like Project Diva games, I'm no expert, but I think this one is worth your time too. You might love the music, or you might not, but you will probably at least like the music enough to really enjoy the high quality of gameplay included within.
