product_title: PDP Afterglow Wired Controller for Xbox 360
review_headline: Excellent Warranty Service (and Longer Than Listed)
review_body:
It works just as well as the official Xbox controller. It glows in the dark, so I can switch off all the lights and plays games in a dark room. But you know that already. So I am gonna tell you about my experience with the customer service and warranty.

I think the warranty period for this controller is 90 days or something. (Most game controllers and mice have three to six month warranty.) I think I bought this controller in May 2014, and its A-button broke in November 2014. The internal spring of the A-button had lost its elasticity. When I pressed the A-button, it would stay down and not bounce back up promptly. That is a very common problem with the A-button because it is the one that is repeatedly pressed and abused the most. So I called up the manufacturer, knowing that the warranty period had expired. I had to call a few times because no one picked up the phone during the first few calls. When I finally got to speak to a customer service rep, he told me not to worry about the warranty. He told me to send the controller back, and they would send me a new one when they received the broken one. I did not have to include the original box or packaging, a printout of the receipt or invoice, or anything else that originally came with the controller. I just had to put the broken controller in an envelop and send it back. I sent it back in its original packaging with all the original materials and a printout of my receipt from Amazon. Then they send a new one to me within a week. (P.S. Their office is located near where I live.)

review_headline: Replaced my Gamepad in a Heartbeat
review_body:
The build quality of this remote is excellent. There's a little give to the buttons, but everything feels spectacular and solid in the hand. It works as expected, and I've been using this as my main remote on my Nvidia Shield TV even though I'm a gamer - it's so convenient, it replaced the gamepad in a heartbeat. The coolest bit? Sue me, but it's the glowing microphone button. It just looks so damn cool. Being able to plug your headphones into the bottom is a close second.

I do have a few minor gripes with the controller. None of them bother me too much, but your mileage may vary.
1. Plastic parts get micro scratches easily, as does all plastic
2. I can't confidently grip this remote as I'm watching stuff on my TV, since the volume control is touch sensitive. Grip it too hard and your volume will start changing.
3. When I plug in my headphones to the port, it comes out relatively easily. There's no "click" or light lock to keep it in there.
4. No dedicated media control buttons. The layout is nice and as an artist who can appreciate simplicity and design, I get why they omitted it. But still, having forward/backward/play buttons would be much more convenient. Fast-forward and rewind is easily one of the biggest inconveniences on Android TV. The difference between using a touch screen to drag a slider vs holding a button to FF (or worse, select 4x speed like on DVD)players) is night and day.

Overall it's a solid remote. The complains I have are mostly informative, so you know exactly what you're getting into. My experience with it has been great, and with the $25 promotion I would say it's a necessity to complement your Shield TV.

product_title: 500GB PlayStation 4 Console - Batman Arkham Knight Bundle
review_body: It arrived broken but Sony was quick to get a new system in my hand ... Beyond that it's the best system on the market... I love it!

The game is simple, the exact same setup as Heavy Rain, and able to be completed, conservatively, in a weekend. The game is captivating and always changing as it jumps along your story line throughout play. Paying $16 for this was a decent price and I'm OK with that, but what makes this 5 stars for me is that it's the most vivid, graphically stunning PS3 game I've ever played. May sound exaggerated, but there are scenes where you watch it and wonder if you magically just got a PS4. This game is coming out for PS4, but doesn't need to b/c the graphics are already comparable. The level of detail in faces & environments will have you wanting more and shaking your head at some moments when you wonder how this game is so beautiful!

If you can rent this game instead, do it, but keep in mind that you can always play this again and take a different story line based on your in-game decisions. Definitely a replayable game, and stunningly beautiful.

review_headline: Elder Scrolls Fan Fiction in MMO form
review_body: I'm going to start off by saying that this is by no means a bad game; in fact, it's quite excellent for an MMO and as taken at face value. Where it goes wrong, I feel, is the Elder Scrolls part of it.  Notice that the game is made by Zenimax and not Bethesa Game Studios (Bethseda Softworks own both). They did as good of a job as they could, but it comes off almost as a fan fiction rendering of the series. I can't help but think while playing it that there's no way that this game will be considered part of the Elder Scrolls canon when they make the next single player ES RPG. Keep in mind while reading my review, that a lot of what I'm talking about was *not* explained in-game and that I figured out a lot of this based upon googling and just playing. It made the experience a little more frustrating than it had to be.  I started as a Nord in the Ebonheart Pact. Just like the other games, you have a choice of the various races (except Imperial class which you have to unlock) and you have a choice between the three alliances. The latter choice will set you in one world until you hit level 50 (in my case, so far, I have access to Dark Elf settlements, argonian areas, and nord areas as well as bits of skyrim here and there) and after that you have to clear the other two in order to complete the game. Once you hit level 10 you have access to the PvP section in Cyrodil, which I haven't much explored yet, but it seems you can become Emperor if you have the highest score on the winning team, which opens up a unique emperor skill tree. The premise, which is not intuitive at all, has you begin in ColdHarbour, the realm of the Daedric prince, Molag Baal. You learn that you are dead, that your soul removed was from your body, and that your goal, effectively, is to stop Molag Baal from breaking through into this world and to get your soul back. Back in Nirn, 1,000 years before the events of Skyrim, there is civil war brewing and the races are forming alliances that are competing for the throne as well as for control over all Tamriel.  THE GOOD: - It's addicting. Though my "bad" section seems to override the good, the only reason for that is because they chose to call this an Elder Scrolls game when they could have easily used the same exact system to create another MMO. It gets better as you play it.  - The main storyline, thus far (I'm at lvl 15), is pretty good. Not up to par with the previous titles but very good for the MMO genre. The main story, the guild storylines, and the overarching war lines are all good. It's the billions of random other ones that are a bit boring and come off pointless. I don't really care about most of the characters because they don't have any distinguishing characteristics or quirks that would make them interesting; all are cookie-cutter versions of each other and each race is a bit of a caricature. Despite that, still enjoyable overall.  - I like that the best way to level up is to complete quests. It just works well for this game.  - The multi-player integration is great too. I thought I'd hate it, but it was a bit fun to pair up with randoms for multiple person dungeons. It can be annoying at times when another player or players beat the boss just as you get there. You get credit for beating the boss without even throwing a punch. When that happens you have to be careful because sometimes when picking up whatever it is you needed from the boss, it respawns and starts hitting you. Hope they fix that. There are annoying sorts - children playing loud music, squeaky mics, domestic disputes - but you can always just leave the chat channel or the chat area. It's pretty much impossible for someone to ruin the experience for you, which is a nice touch.  THE BAD: -It's technically not free. You have to pay for a playstation plus subscription. I just paid for 3 months for $18, and given that, you get game discounts and free game downloads; it's really not that bad price-wise, but it is important to state thatdespite removing their subscription fee, it's still not free to play on consoles.  - The game is all in real time, so there is no saving or pausing. The no pausing drives me crazy because even when you're looking at your inventory or map, things/people can hurt and kill you. When you die, you have a choice to go to the nearest wayshrine or respawn using a full soul gem corresponding to your level. Also, the game logs you out after 20 minutes of inactivity.  - As mentioned, the fast travel system needs a bit of work. It's not intuitive and the PvP and PvE are not mutually compatible for fast travel, which is understandable, but there is no real instruction on how to travel to Cyrodil once you hit level 10 and it's a bit tricky to get back to the PvE engine from Cyrodil (I had to google this and look at multiple places before I figured it out).  - The leveling system, though I've heard that they've fix a few issues, is still ridiculous. What I dislike most about it is that there is no way really to get ahead with super cool armor or a cool rare weapon - every object is given a 'level' and you cannot use, equip, eat or drink anything that is above your level. I've gone ahead and completed quests that were way out of my skill range, received the rewards, only to just drop them off at the bank for storage until I hit that level. This also gives us no incentive to keep or store lower-ranked objects no matter what they are. I just destroy the objects below my ranking because there's no point.  - I feel no incentive to learn enchanting as you can easily find enchanted objects throughout the world. All the other skills such as provisioning, alchemy, woodwork, blacksmithing, leatherwork, etc are pretty boring, unnecessarily complicated, and it seems like everything is made at a much lower level than I'm at (since each of these traits have their own levels/skill trees). It makes it feel pointless, but then again, I haven't really been spending my precious skill points on any of these skills because as a non-subscriber, you don't get them very often.  - Every time you level up, complete a major quest, or collect 3 skyshards you get 1 skill point to spend. Those skills points can be used to purchase special moves, 'ultimate' abilities, or passive traits. There are a ton of skill trees, but when you don't have a subscription it takes a bit longer to level up, which makes it feel incredible slow and monotonous at times. When purchasing special moves for a weapon type (they have bow (all have infinity arrows), 1 hand/shield, dual wielding, two handed, and staff), you assign each move to a button on your controller. The fighting system is a little boring at times because you cannot do what i like to do, which is sneak around and pick people off, not only because of the system but because it seems like enemies respawn in the exact area within a minute (sometimes out of thin air which is annoying). As a lvl 15, I've unlocked weapon swapping but i haven't really utilized this yet.  - Graphics are cartoonish and disappointing in the context of next-gen tech.   - Both jumping and interacting are through the X button, meaning that if there is an interactable object in front of you, you will interact with the object instead of jumping. This was irritating when my character would get stuck between solid objects and I couldn't jump away because there was a damn crate in front of me.   - One of my favorite things about the ES games was that everything was interactable and the stories/characterization were always consistent. In this game, they've simplified its interactiveness. An example would be that you can only read one book from each bookshelf, each container if not empty has one random item in it, potions are just simply marked "alchemy bottle" or "drink," you cannot see the stats for the weapons/armor laying around the world  without picking it up, and most items/dead people are non-interactable. There is literally no way to tell which items you can pick up or not unless you get close to them. As for the inconsistent characterizations/stories, it feels like a fanfiction. Playing in Ebonheart pact, I've noticed they've just pretty much thrown in flora/fauna from other games haphazardly. There is scathcrow all over the place (instead of just being near the volcanic/dark elf areas), there are the large Telvanni mushrooms all over the place (even though the lore states that they're special to that house of dark elves), every Argonian has a hypenated name, and every Nord is a boisterous drunk. Sounds a bit nitpicky,I know, but its those attention to details that really made me fall in love with the previous titles.  OVERALL:  NOT A BAD GAME. It is enjoyable for what it is and the ES title is what is going to get people to buy it. If you are an MMO fan, you will love this. If you are an Elder Scrolls fan, it could go either way. I play video games for storyline and immersion, so my gripes will not be the same as other people's gripes. I'd suggest people at least try it. I didn't like it at all at first, but as I'm cheap, I kept on playing and it sort of grew on me.
I love it!

product_title: PDP AG7 True Wireless Headset for Xbox One
review_headline: NOT a good headset for chatting
review_body:
The sound is great and not having cords is awesome. But if you want to use it for chat, forget it. The microphone does not have enough pick up, even when pulled as close as you can to your mouth, the other folks on chat still have a hard time hearing me. They say it's like I'm talking to them from another room. Which is kind of annoying, since chatting is the whole point of a wireless headset when you are multi-player gaming.

In fact, I gave it up and went back to my old headset (XO One) relatively quickly.

review_headline: This charging solution was the only one on the market that actually looked somewhat nice (and much more presentable than having
review_body: Gave up waiting for Sony to release the official DS4 charging cradle and black vertical stand, and finally bought the import versions here.  This charging solution was the only one on the market that actually looked somewhat nice (and much more presentable than having USB cables hanging off the front of the PS4).  Inserting the DS4 into the cradle is hit or miss, and it usually takes me a good minute or two to get one seated correctly if the lighting is dim (which I can live with).  Other than that, it looks nice and works perfectly on 120V US power as shipped.  EDIT: just realized that a DS4 will actually drop itself gently onto the charger's connector when placed in the cradle, which seems to work much better than trying to line up the connectors and pushing the controller into place.

review_headline: This game plays a lot like Vanquish, so if you're looking for something similar ...
review_body:
I don't understand much Japanese; but if you're into crazy Japanese action games then this is a definite buy. This game plays a lot like Vanquish, so if you're looking for something similar this game is a definite buy in that case.

Pros
- Controls are easy to learn, even if you don't understand Japanese
- Gameplay scales perfectly with difficulty
- Plot is really straight forward so even non Japanese players can understand what the situation is.
- Great Soundtrack

Cons
- Never came to America
- Dead Multiplayer
- The Camera can sometimes work against you.

review_headline: Avoid - fire stick remote is better than this thing
review_body:
I purchased this hoping to replace my current amazon fire stick with a beefier device (xbone).

I mistakenly assumed that this would be wireless/bluetooth, not IR. In 2015 I would hope we would no longer need to point a remote directly at a console for it to function, but I guess Microsoft disagrees.

Pros:

* Looks nice
* Functions
* Volume controls work with TV, which is nice

Cons

* IR, not bluetooth/wireles. In my case, while I can see the xbone there is a table in front of it that often blocks this remote from functioning half the time.
* Very heavy - I'd guess 3x as heavy as the fire stick remote
* Very thick - Again, easily 3x as thick as the fire stick remote

Conclusion: For an extra ~$10, get a fire stick. Don't bother with this thing.

product_title: 500GB PlayStation 4 Console - Batman Arkham Knight Bundle
review_body:
I've been playing for 2 weeks now, and just got to 98% on Arkham Knight, which was a fun game even if I disliked the game's ending .I bought this bundle because I got it on a day where Amazon gave me $20 in credit on top of me using a bunch of saved up bonus points making it almost free. Really, the only reason I was getting a PS4 was to play Fallout 4 and Star Wars Battlefront, but they don't come out till November. The deal made me bite early. I'm glad I did!

Close to the first thing I did was swap out the hard drive for a SSHD 1 TB drive as I knew the space on 500 GB would run out fast (trust me, Arkham Knight itself, even playing off a disk, requires a 50 GB install - so, 8 games and the drive would be full). The swap out was so painless and easy I couldn't believe it. granted, I have some experience with such things, but honestly, it was so easy anyone could do it.

The drive came 1 day after the system, and I couldn't resist, so I spent the first day playing games on the stock hard drive. There were updates that needed installed, and then there were my save files. Transferring these to the new hard drive was effortless as well. On a USB 3.0 thumbstick (128 GB) it took me 35 minutes to copy 75 GB off the stock drive, and then after the new drive was installed and initialized, about 45 minutes to copy it back onto the system. I did it in between mowing the lawn and doing laundry and it was click and forget it for each step. set up the process, go mow the lawn, come back and it was done. perfect.

product_title: Pirates of the Caribbean Dead Man's Chest - Sony PSP
review_headline: Seller Was Great, the Game... Not So Much
review_body: The game came on time and in the case, in the exact condition as was said. I had no problem with the seller, but with the game. The graphics are pretty nice and the animations are far from bad, too, but after awhile the gameplay gets repetitive. The story is bare-bones, the puzzles can hardly be called such, and it's difficult to play even an entire level before getting bored. I would recommend the seller, but I'm afraid the game just isn't that good.

I'm a big fan of giant robot anime and a love Saturn games that combine 2D and 3D. This game is a perfect blend. While your ship/robot is 2D sprites the enemies and level are in 3D. There's horrible draw-in but I don't mind a bit because there's a super helpful radar, perfectly designed levels, and absolutely gorgeous high-speed graphics.

The game has it's main menu in English but the controls and mission briefings are in Japanese. This isn't a problem because the objectives are straightforward and the controls can be figured out in a minute or three.

I've played a lot of games like this over the years (robot war-machines fighting in cities) but this is the most anime-like of any of them, with the best controls, the best graphics, and the most fun gameplay by far.

If you love Saturn action games and especially if you love giant robot anime you are going to love this game. It is worth the high price.

review_headline: Just what the doctor ordered (sort of)
review_body:
After playing a mentally exhausting game like Bloodborne, I needed something 'light' to hold me over until Mad Max comes out. LEGO Marvel fit the bill, and was just what the doctor ordered.

Combat -- Well, the type of combat really hinges on who you're playing as. Guys like Iron Man (easily my favorite hero to play with in the game) are better suited to use ranged attacks. However, if you're playing as Hulk or Thing, melee combat is pretty much your only option. If I can be honest, the combat isn't really fun, regardless of who you're playing as. It's a LEGO game, so I wasn't expecting much anyway. As for dodging or blocking incoming attacks; again, it depends on who you're playing as. If you're Captain America, you can use your shield to send projectiles flying back at the enemy. There's not a button dedicated to dodging, so if you're not playing as a character that has a shield, you'll be S.O.L. in some cases. Not to worry though, I pretty much went through the entire game without dying. Now that I think about it, I'm not sure you -can- die...

Weaponry -- I know I sound like a broken record, but it depends on which character you're playing as. I'm not super familiar with the Marvel characters, so I'm not going to attempt to name all of these guys and their powers. If you're a Marvel fan, I'm pretty sure they have the same powers that they have in the comic books and movies. Captain America has his shield, Thor has his hammer, Storm uses her tornado, etc. I didn't play as too many different characters, so I only know of a couple of guys that can use the environment as a weapon, and that would be Hulk and Thing. I wish more characters could make use of the environment, such as the gameplay in Ultimate Alliance II. Oh my, I can't believe I just said something good about that game. I must not be feeling well...

Enemies -- None of the enemies are difficult, and they're not very diverse. There are a few that use projectiles, but most of them just run at you and hit you. The heck with it, I'm just going to come out and say it. You can probably beat most of the enemies with your eyes closed. I found most of the boss battles to be pretty lame, except for the one against my favorite villain :-) Alright, here's how most of the boss battles go:
1) Destroy a fixture of LEGOs.
2) Use the scattered LEGOs to build a new LEGO fixture.
3) Use said fixture of LEGOs as a weapon against the boss, and he'll lose 1 heart of health.
4) Repeat steps 1-3 until you deplete all of their hearts.
This process is actually more lame than it sounds...

Miscellaneous -- If you decide to play through the story mode and skip all of side-missions, it's probably a 15 hour game, at the most. There are a ton of side-missions, but I can't really speak to how much fun they are, because I only completed 2 of them. After completing a level, you'll automatically unlock free-play, which means you can replay the level and use any of the unlocked characters. Although this game is lacking in a lot of areas, it excels in providing challenging puzzles. I hate to admit this, but I relied on YouTube to aid me in a couple of puzzles, so beware. The main hub is in NYC, and I enjoyed driving around town, trolling some of the LEGO residents :-) I chose to only spend 15 hours on it, but there's definitely at least 50 hours of gameplay awaiting anyone that's interested.

LEGO Marvel was just a filler game for me, and it served its purpose. I was very impressed with how complex some of the puzzles were, but the game as a whole was kind of meh at times (especially when I was unable to play as Iron Man). Although LEGO Marvel wasn't a great game, it was the perfect game to followup a brutal 88 hour slugfest like Bloodborne. I needed something light and vanilla, and that combination rarely results in 5 star game, so I think 3 stars is appropriate. Mad Max; you're up next!them just run at you and hit you. The heck with it, I'm just going to come out and say it. You can probably beat most of the enemies with your eyes closed. I found most of the boss battles to be pretty lame, except for the one against my favorite villain :-) Alright, here's how most of the boss battles go:
1) Destroy a fixture of LEGOs.
2) Use the scattered LEGOs to build a new LEGO fixture.
3) Use said fixture of LEGOs as a weapon against the boss, and he'll lose 1 heart of health.
4) Repeat steps 1-3 until you deplete all of their hearts.
This process is actually more lame than it sounds...

Miscellaneous -- If you decide to play through the story mode and skip all of side-missions, it's probably a 15 hour game, at the most. There are a ton of side-missions, but I can't really speak to how much fun they are, because I only completed 2 of them. After completing a level, you'll automatically unlock free-play, which means you can replay the level and use any of the unlocked characters. Although this game is lacking in a lot of areas, it excels in providing challenging puzzles. I hate to admit this, but I relied on YouTube to aid me in a couple of puzzles, so beware. The main hub is in NYC, and I enjoyed driving around town, trolling some of the LEGO residents :-) I chose to only spend 15 hours on it, but there's definitely at least 50 hours of gameplay awaiting anyone that's interested.

LEGO Marvel was just a filler game for me, and it served its purpose. I was very impressed with how complex some of the puzzles were, but the game as a whole was kind of meh at times (especially when I was unable to play as Iron Man). Although LEGO Marvel wasn't a great game, it was the perfect game to followup a brutal 88 hour slugfest like Bloodborne. I needed something light and vanilla, and that combination rarely results in 5 star game, so I think 3 stars is appropriate. Mad Max; you're up next!

Hands down the most fun I've ever had with a video game. Ever since I received it, there has been a steady flow of new content released which keeps it "fresh" ("Stay fresh!"). Everything in the game is a clever sea related word play. The story and premise is clever and original. Gameplay is smooth and fairly easy to learn but difficult to master, which makes it easy to keep interest. Matches are quick, so you don't have to commit an hour just to play a match - 3 minutes for standard play, 5 minutes or less on the more competitive ranked play. Matchmaking ensures you aren't playing against people way above your skill level, and doesn't let it get boring as you get better by giving you harder opponents as you advance. The bright colors are fun and make it interesting for kids/spouses.

Cons:
I wish there was local multiplayer so my wife could play on my team. Instead we just take turns every other match.
There is occasional lag which provides an unexpected death, but that's forgivable every once in a while.

Overall, while this is a shooter game, it doesn't feel that way. It feels more like a friendly game of paintball or laser tag. It's family friendly and ridiculously fun.

product_title: REACT SOUND PSP AUDIO SPEAKER SYSTEM
review_body: I purchased this system back in 2006 for use with my Playstation Portable. I found this unit at a local Best Buy for a total of $50.00 and I was pretty impressed. Its been years since I purchased this little system and I now have upgraded to Audio Engine 2+'s and A5+'s and a great subwoofer. It's now 2015... But I'll be honest, these little cheap Chinese speakers... Are pure Gold when it comes to amazing audio... If you can find this little system today, you better buy them, I've abused the hell out this little speaker system for nearly 8 years and they still work... In fact they still sound incredible even in comparison to to my amazing Audio Engine A2+'s and my A5+'s this company may have disappeared but they left behind a legacy to those who happened to luckily stumble upon them. These speakers paired with a decent sub and desktop setup are amazing... I wish I could buy these again. I'm not crazy either, this little system was hugely overlooked and if you happen to find one for sale, buy them!
Really expensive but you'll probably need to get one if depending on how much you play.

Waited awhile before leaving feedback to make sure it worked for awhile. Works perfectly fine, no problems with the Wii console or the controllers. Very happy with product & service! Everything was packed very good & received it quickly.

review_headline: Good game. Still a bit buggy but it is ...
review_body: Good game. Still a bit buggy but it is tolerable now. Ubisoft still has a way to go if they plan to use this same system in their newer AC games. The combat system is different than previous games. Instead of Dodge rolling, you now have Parry. But I love the fact you can CUSTOMIZE EVERY PIECE OF YOUR OUTFIT FROM THE LOOKS TO THE COLORS AND CREATE A TRULY UNIQUE LOOK.

review_headline: Blade Runner in Everything But Name
review_body:
Loving this game so far. It's like Blade Runner and Ghost in the Shell made into a video game. If you're into cyberpunk/tech noir, you must play this. Lots of nods to works of PKD, Sterling, Gibson, etc. Soundtrack is very atmospheric, very similar to Burial or Vangelis.

Few issues:

World needs to be bigger, more open.
Button combinations a little inconsistent when hacking. Get rid of the 'release X' thing as it doesn't always work. Just use Dpad.
Need ability to drop items into containers. Leaving them on the floor feels messy.
Voice acting is top-notch; mouth movement ain't.
Need dedicated map button. Having everything under Back button gets tedious.
Need transparent map overlay so I don't have to stop running to look at it, hence dedicated map button.
The right product

product_title: Turtle Beach - Ear Force Recon 30X Chat Communicator Gaming Headset - Xbox One (compatible w/ new Xbox One controller), PS4, PC, Mac, and Mobile
review_body:
Yuckadoo.

My two teens go through headsets and ear buds like Cheerios so I'm always on the look out for inexpensive gear. (Sometimes mom and dad pays and sometimes they pay.)

As far as ear buds what I've purchased about 10x is Panasonics cheap little $6 dollar product. Here's an ASIN -- B003EM6AOG -- they come in a bunch of colors and price can vary a little with color. We haven't discovered any quality difference with the different colors. They are cheap and good enough to enjoy most music and gaming sounds.

WHAT I was looking for here is the Headset equivalent. Something to be used for Skyping in particular as that seems to be the thing these days. My kids can't game without chatting with friends. This headset is not good enough though for this price.

WHAT I FOUND
-- plug and play works fine. No problem using them.
-- sound quality was not even $6 dollar good.
-- uncomfortable to wear. With only 1 ear pad you would think comfort would be easy to accomplish. Not so. Granted, daughter child and I have big heads. If you have a big head, avoid.
-- cord feels cheap. Of course it doesn't really matter as long as the cord holds up, but it feels cheap.
-- I like the L-shaped plug

SUMMARY
Too pricey for you get. I'd avoid these if you have a large noggin.

product_title: Turtle Beach - Ear Force XO One Amplified Gaming Headset - Xbox One
review_body:
Probably the best headset possible for $60 shipped. Great, not necessarily amazing sound quality. Had all the functionality I wanted, such as broadcasting my own voice back to me, game sounds playing through the headset, and a removable mic so it can function as ipod headphones without looking stupid walking around town. Came with the nice proprietary stereo adaptor, which can change the game volume / chat volume balance.

You won't get a headset better than this unless you spend twice this, or more. 5 stars for affordably exceeding all expectations!
great

I absolutely hated this game. I may just be a different kind of fan of video game genre or may have totally missed the mark on this one and souley purchased this because bungie was attached to the name but this game is NOTHING compared to ANY of the Halo franchise games. There is no storyline, or great video clips to get you excited about the next mission. It is the same brainless mission over and over again and when you do see others playing alongside you, no one is willing to join your party, play with you and half the missions are so difficult you get lost in it all. There are some areas that require a higher level to enter and actually defeat the opponents but the game never specifies or explains any of this.

I personally am a fan of halo, mass effect, tomb raider, assassins creed, and uncharted... Not one of these games are even similar to this one. I absolutely hated every mission and felt empty after completing any quest.

If you also were looking for games I mentioned.. Do yourself a favor and avoid this game at all cost. I really did try to like this game. I would leave it for days,weeks, and even a month and came back to play hoping it was just my mood at the time, but I ended up not even finishing or caring.
Does not run on our XBOX 360.

review_body: This is a great product. If you play station is like mine, it stays dusty. This product is not put together. When you get it you will need to assemble the screen and the two plastic pieces. Make sure you look at the sides as they are different. One side of the screen and plastic is diagonal and the other side is straight.  It was a little hard to get the pieces together. One they are together and you are going to put them on the machine you will need to look at the sides as the diagonal side goes to the front.  The instructions are not that great but it's easy to figure out. It also comes with port covers so if you are using a USB port you can cover it so dust stays out. So far it looks like it might work. And if the screens become too dusty they give you two more screens as replacements.

review_headline: A fun game to play with the kids
review_body: A fun game to play with the kids. This is one of the only games that my son truly enjoys playing with his "uncool dad". DO NOT BUY FOR XBOX ONE  If you want to buy for the campaign mode then go for it. Multiplayer is terrible--TERRIBLE!!! Before I start this review I have 10+ Years of computer networking experience, I have already configured my router to every possible combination, I.E port forwarding, NAT open, DMZ ETC!!! So it is NOT my network connection. Also all my other multiplayer games work flawlessly except for this turd. well were shall I begin, 1: It laggy you will glitch and get a so called "rubber band effect" 2. good luck finding more than 10 servers when doing server browser. Quick match works but it will stick you in a map by yourself with no other players 99.9% of the time. You have to constantly refresh. 3. Most of the servers you DO find are full and you will have to keep trying in the hopes that someone will disconnect . 4. All the other stuff is tolerable but THIS!!! is a deal-breaker. I WILL NOT!!!! stay connected to a server. So it takes 20 min to join a server then I start playing and after about 10 minutes I disconnect with some bogus error. this happens 9 times out of 10.  This game has been out for a few years for the xbox one now and it is still SEVERELY BROKEN!!!! EA/WHQ doesn't care don't waste your time with their customer support as they are about as worthless as this game is. I didn't even bother getting Hardline because this one was so terrible. Do yourself a favor, if you want to play this game do it on PC...At least there it works. I have the premium pack and all I can say it is a poor investment (EVEN USED)  maybe some day EA and the powers that be will step up and fix this with a patch  but i wouldn't hold your breath.

review_headline: so my step-daughter needed a fun one to play the Wii with too
review_body: Who WOULDN'T want a pink Wii remote?  My boys have the Mario & Luigi remotes, so my step-daughter needed a fun one to play the Wii with too!  It works perfectly with the Wii U, you just need to sync it before use.  I'm so glad that a silicone cover comes with it.  Normally if you buy a Wii remote, you have to purchase those separately. If you have a Wii gamer in your house, BUY this.  They'll feel special having their own remote to play with!  LOVE LOVE LOVE this product!  Wish I could give it more stars!

review_headline: Yeah, COD on the DS. and it's BLACK OPS!
review_body:
I admit, I have the WII edition of this game and it's better yes, but this one has some cool things in it. I will start with a pros and cons list, pros first.
PROS
-Call of Duty Black Ops for the DS!
-Lots of missions and mini game to help you keep playing.
-Zombies is the best, but hard! More of a challenge.
-The guns feel and look great on a piklelated screen.
-This games campaign is not the same on the console one, but they are both about two of the guys (Sgt. Michale Shaw and Capt. Alex Massion.) as the story will say stuff for each of the characters.
CONS
-The story, while decent, ends after the last missions with no one "After Mission Debrifing". It makes me wonder what happened and why there isn't a Call of Duty Black Ops ll for the 3ds.
-Zombies have an unfair advantage on you, one hit and your dead. You also have a one hit kill weapon till wave eight then you need to get the power ups.
-I have not been able to try the multiplayer yet as DS has shut down the online servers and there are no bots for local. My sister has a DS, but won't get this game.

Over all, this is possibly the best DS game ever. Save your money and get this game AND a console version and have a load of fun!

product_title: Grip-iT Analog Stick Covers, Set of 4
review_body: I've been using these grips for about six months now, and they've been pretty durable. Originally I only needed them because the left analog stick on my DS4 was wearing through and had a rip in it, which was annoying for gaming. I didn't want the rip to get larger so I searched for some grips, and at the time this is the best I could find. They're extremely grippy, and after hours of use they are still grippy which I see as a plus. Definitely makes using the DS4 controller a better experience and I don't have to worry about the analog sticks getting worse. These have lasted me a great while and have not noticed any wearing through, like I've seen mentioned in a few reviews. I use my DS4 heavily daily also, so it's not a lack of use. I would recommend these based off durability and prolonged use - especially to make your DS4 analog sticks last longer.

review_headline: it's terrible. Honestly it's a waste of money even at ...
review_body:
#1 - This is rip-off plain and simple. You can buy this game through the XBox marketplace for $19.99, or through GameStop for the same price. The game is basically just an update to the '14 edition with small changes, hence the lower price. That this is being listed here for $50 is nothing more or less then somebody trying to make a dollar at your expense.

As for the game, it's terrible. Honestly it's a waste of money even at $20. There are numerous reviews around the internet of this game, and it's all pretty much the same, the gameplay is poor, the cars handle terribly, there is no realism in the AI, the career mode is poorly thought out, it's filled with bugs and glitches that are so obvious that they either didn't test it or just didn't care enough to fix what are some very glaring issues. It's basically a (standalone) update to NASCAR 14, but there are many things which they did nothing to update. For example, the NASCAR All-Star race in this game used a format that was used once - in 2012. I haven't played any installment of this game prior to this one, but that's a pretty glaring mistake, shows that the developers of this game either don't care about NASCAR, don't know what's in their game, or just don't care. It's a pathetic offering that is put to shame by other racing games.

product_title: The Witcher 2: Assassins Of Kings - Enhanced Edition - Xbox 360
review_headline: A Rewarding and Replayable RPG (but not for the faint of heart!)
review_body:
A challenging, unique, and absorbing twist on the high fantasy RPG formula, The Witcher 2 revels in both rich world-building and inventive gameplay encounters.

As Geralt of Rivia, a seasoned monster hunter with a case of amnesia and nasty habit of falling in with dangerous company, players are thrust into a riveting story of their own choosing: shades of revenge-drama, political thriller, and good ol' fashion mythical questing flesh out Geralt's search for his past and redemption. Cut into four distinctive and diverging chapters based off players' choices in-game, Geralt's journey stretches from lushly detailed forests to war ravaged wastelands, each of which hold beasts waiting to be felled and hugely entertaining side-quests to be completed.

Combat is tactical and quite rewarding given patience and strategy. Slicing and dicing baddies, then breaking out a combo with magic runes and gadgets makes for massive fun. The game's visuals are beautiful on the 360, as well, particularly the great array of environments. Unfortunately, the game relies heavily on invisible fencing and has some awkward environmental navigation issues, often leading to frustrating situations that detract from the fun. Likewise, the game has a tough learning curve, so casual players may feel less compelled to stick with the lengthy campaign even on easier settings. Still, Assassins of Kings is a compelling, brutal ride to the dark side of fantasy no RPG fan should miss!

review_headline: While the spring loaded docking system is nice in some aspects
review_body: Works well for what it does, it charges my controllers. While the spring loaded docking system is nice in some aspects, it makes things a bit difficult when the spring either fails to stay locked down or when a controller is removed without "unlatching" the spring. When this occurs it's almost impossible for me to get the controller redocked without picking up the charging station and finicking with lining the ports up. That being said, when the springs are in the "unlatched" position it's very easy to line them up and start charging.

review_headline: I loved smash bros on the Wii
review_body: I loved smash bros on the Wii, but I have to say that even on our 60" TV this version for the WiiU is chaos.  Not in a good way.  The maps are very large, therefore the mass of characters on screen are very tiny.  When the melee begins and the camera is constantly zooming and panning across the large stages it becomes near impossible to keep track of your character on screen.  My husband is able to manage, but I won't be playing this game again.
